lg.l: Well; if ever I saw such another man since my Mother bound my head,
You a Gentleman! marry come up, I wonder where you were bred?
I'm sure such words does not become a man of your Cloth,
I would not give such language to a dog, faith & troth.
Yes; you call'd my Master Knave: Fie Mṛ Sheridan, tis a shame
For a Parson, that shoud know better things, to come out wth such a name.
Knave in your teeth, Mṛ Sheridan 'tis both a shame & a sin,
And ye Dean my Master is an honester man than you & all your kin:
He has more goodness in his little finger, than you have in your whole body,
My Master is a parsonable man, & not a spindleshank'd hoddy doddy.
And now whereby I find you wou'd fain make an excuse,
Because my Master one day in anger call'd you goose.
Which & I am sure I have been his servant four years since October
And he never call'd me worse than sweetheart drunk or sober:
Not that I know his Reverence was ever concern'd to my knowledge,
Tho' you & your Comerogues keep him out so late in your colledge.
You say you will eat grass on his grave a Christian eat grass!
Whereby you confess yourself to be a Goose or an Ass:
But that's as much as to say that my Master shoud die before ye,
Well, well, that's as God pleases, & I dont believe that's a true story,
And so say I told you so, & you may go tell my Master; what care I?
And I don't care who knows it, 'tis all one to Mary.
Every body knows, that I love to tell truth and shame ye Devil,
I am but a poor Servant but I think gentlefolks should be civil.
Besides you found fault wth our Vittles one day when you was here
I remember it was on a tuesday, of all day in ye year.
And Saunders ye man says, you are always jesting & mocking,
Mary said he (one day, as I was mending my Masters stocking,)
My Master is so fond of that minister that keeps ye School;
I thought my Master a wise man but that man makes him a fool.
Saunders, said I, I had rather than a quart of ale
He wou'd come into our Kitchen, & I wou'd pin a dishclout to his tail.
And now I must go & get Saunders to direct this letter,
For I write but a sad scrawl, but my sister Marget she writes better.
Well, but I must run & make ye bed before my Master comes from pray'rs,
And see now, it strikes ten, & I hear him coming up Stairs:
Whereof I cou'd say more to your Verses if I cou'd write written hand,
And so I remain in a civil way, Your Servant to commandMary.985-102M
